tags: hes not perfect but he sure as hell is not the villain
summary: If I see one more post calling Bran the “villain” of the show, I will lose it. He explained in the show why he couldn’t tell...
body: If I see one more post calling Bran the “villain” of the show, I will lose it. He explained in the show why he couldn’t tell everyone what he knows, everyone just wants a scapegoat to blame for Dany’s death. He did what he had to do for the kingdom, not because he was some power-hungry throne seeker. And if y’all can’t see that, rewatch the show so you can figure it out for yourself.

reblog.comment: If I see one more post calling Bran the “villain” of the show, I will lose it. He explained in the show why he couldn’t tell everyone what he knows, everyone just wants a scapegoat to blame for Dany’s death. He did what he had to do for the kingdom, not because he was some power-hungry throne seeker. And if y’all can’t see that, rewatch the show so you can figure it out for yourself.

trail.content_raw: If I see one more post calling Bran the “villain” of the show, I will lose it. He explained in the show why he couldn’t tell everyone what he knows, everyone just wants a scapegoat to blame for Dany’s death. He did what he had to do for the kingdom, not because he was some power-hungry throne seeker. And if y’all can’t see that, rewatch the show so you can figure it out for yourself.
trail.content: If I see one more post calling Bran the “villain” of the show, I will lose it. He explained in the show why he couldn’t tell everyone what he knows, everyone just wants a scapegoat to blame for Dany’s death. He did what he had to do for the kingdom, not because he was some power-hungry throne seeker. And if y’all can’t see that, rewatch the show so you can figure it out for yourself.

blog.name: mother-of-the-fandom
blog.title: Isaac Hempstead Wright
blog.description: Like a woman about to go forth in SIN -  this blog does contain NSFW posts

summary: It’s just so obvious to me that Sansa never wanted to be left in Winterfell alone, and I think that’s part of why her coronation...
body:
It’s just so obvious to me that Sansa never wanted to be left in Winterfell alone, and I think that’s part of why her coronation was so sad for me.

Even when Arya and Bran returned home, she missed Jon a lot. When Jon was home, Sansa spent most of her time with him. They would walk together, plan together, sit beside each other, etc. It’s like they were inseparable.

When Jon leaves, Sansa starts doing some of those same activities with Littlefinger and later Yohn Royce. She hangs out with her siblings too but it’s not the same as it was with Jon. She actually remarkably closer to Jon than she is with Bran or Arya at that point. And she keeps his crown ready for him instead of ceasing power for herself.

Littlefinger asks her why. He asks her why she’s not happy. And I think we’re supposed to get a sense of… she’s not happy to be alone or to be surrounded by men who aren’t allies. She’s not happy Jon is away and in danger.

Arya lurks off. She wasn’t even present when Jon arrives, and Sansa and Arya spent a long time being at odds and trying to figure out their new relationship because they are so different now. Sansa always knew Arya would leave too. Everyone does. We all know Arya won’t be staying North all her life helping Sansa run the North. It’s not her. Arya for all her attendance at larger meetings and events, isn’t going to stay up late running numbers and reading scrolls.

Bran is… not Bran anymore. He brings up Sansa’s traumatic memories which is pretty shitty and I’d be a bit afraid of him at that point. He’s not comforting to be around and he has no interest in any truly human affairs. He’s not going to be sticking around to be Lord of Winterfell. Being around him is lonely and only reminds his siblings of the brother they have lost.

But Jon. Jon was King in the North. Jon loves the North. Jon never wants to leave the North. Winterfell is his home. It’s where he’s always wanted to live. He’s always wanted to be a Stark. And now that Sansa shares all the same sentiments of valuing her Starkness and never wanting to leave the North and Winterfell, they have such common goals for their futures. She can rule with Jon. And I think that’s her dream of the future: an independent North ruled by her and Jon. She never expects Jon to want to leave or to not end up in Winterfell with her at the end of this. And it’s telling that she’s okay sharing that power… especially even after all he’s done to undermine Northern independence - she still wants him back home.

Jon being with another woman, especially a Southerner and especially someone who wants to subjugate the North, crushes that dream Initially though. It’s not something she was expecting out of him. Even if she doesn’t want him romantically (which I think she does), his new queen takes up a place in his life that boxes her out.

It’s telling to me that in Sansas goodbye she says “they lost their king” because honestly they lost him a long time ago. When Jon bent the knee they lost him. When the Northern lords who made Jon king wanted to unmake him, they lost him. He gave up his crown, and yet Sansa was always trying to get it back to him. She always trying to fix his mistakes and get power back into his hands, and get him back to Winterfell. She still always wanted Jon to be King and her to be Lady of Winterfell and for them to rule together basically like they had before he went South.

blog.name: gisellesaintclaire
blog.title: Friend, hero, connoisseur of snacks
blog.description: I will defend Skyler White and Sansa Stark until my dying breath

summary: "Mother will be home soon. Maybe we can ride out to meet her when she comes. Wouldn't that surprise her, to see you ahorse?"...
body:
“Mother will be home soon. Maybe we can ride out to meet her when she comes. Wouldn’t that surprise her, to see you ahorse?” Even in the dark room, Bran could feel his brother’s smile. “And afterward, we’ll ride north to see the Wall. We won’t even tell Jon we’re coming, we’ll just be there one day, you and me. It will be an adventure.” “An adventure,” Bran repeated wistfully. He heard his brother sob. The room was so dark he could not see the tears on Robb’s face, so he reached out and found his hand. Their fingers twined together.

Bran IV, A Game of Thrones

Bran IV, A Game of Thrones

summary: "Will I truly be able to ride?" Bran asked. He wanted to believe them, but he was afraid. Perhaps it was just another lie. The...
body:
“Will I truly be able to ride?” Bran asked. He wanted to believe them, but he was afraid. Perhaps it was just another lie. The crow had promised him that he could fly.

Bran IV, A Game of Thrones

blog.name: buttercuparry
blog.title: Warm Winter Sun
blog.description: If a 12 year old has to save the world then so be it!

summary: In regards to your posts abt canon... there was  a new interview today with Isaac H.W where he says that D&D told him that Bran...
question: In regards to your posts abt canon... there was  a new interview today with Isaac H.W where he says that D&D told him that Bran was always going to be King. You said it seemed as though they were on the right track to the right endgames and just decided to not do them... but if that’s true? Where does that leave Bran’s endgame then and what does that mean for the others then? They never even set his story up properly for that but they still did it... (1/2)
answer:
2/2 I think the endgame will be the same and ppl holding out for differences are gonna be disappointed. As I’ve thought abt it in regards to Arya I think there is a way that would make sense for her to leave but I don’t think she will be alone (not with Jon or Gendry, but with her baby. Gendry will die and some drama will occur between those 3 that leaves Arya and Jon’s relationship strained by the end). I don’t want her to leave but her staying doesn’t seem to be what GRRM is writing.

Hi nonnie. I am very sorry for the late reply.

So moving on to your question about Bran’s endgame in the books. I do think that he will end up as a king. In fact ruling Winterfell is something that’s heavily foreshadowed in Bran’s storyline. From as early as AGoT we see Bran claiming to feel like a lord of the castle:

Bran could perch for hours among the shapeless, rain-worn gargoyles that brooded over the First Keep, watching it all: the men drilling with wood and steel in the yard, the cooks tending their vegetables in the glass garden, restless dogs running back and forth in the kennels, the silence of the godswood, the girls gossiping beside the washing well. It made him feel like he was lord of the castle, in a way even Robb would never know.

In ACoK we see him presiding over the harvest feast and learning the simple nuances of politics. I also think that out of all the siblings Bran is the one who is most connected to this ancient seat of House Stark.

…Beyond, the tops of the keeps and towers still stood as they had for hundreds of years, and it was hard to tell that the castle had been sacked and burned at all. The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought. I’m not dead either.

The fact that he compares himself to Winterfell is very telling in itself. So how can Bran then end the series by moving away from Winterfell, the place from where he draws his strength? It wouldn’t make any sense if George just plucks him out of the North to plop him down in Kingslanding, a place that once represented Bran’s dreams of being a knight.

Now as for Arya. I would be really disappointed if George makes her sail off to some unknown land after focusing so much on the importance of her family and the North in her povs. Take this excerpt for example:

If only she could climb like Bran, she thought; she would go out the window and down the tower, run away from this horrible place, away from Sansa and Septa Mordane and Prince Joffrey, from all of them. Steal some food from the kitchens, take Needle and her good boots and a warm cloak. She could find Nymeria in the wild woods below the Trident, and together they’d return to Winterfell, or run to Jon on the Wall.

This is just after Mycah’s death and Arya feels miserable in the Red Keep. And what does she think of doing? Arya wants to run away to Winterfell or to Jon at the Wall. So even before she loses everything, Arya longs to return home.

…but Yoren at least must have a grave, Arya had insisted. He was going to bring me safe to Winterfell, he promised. Part of her wanted to cry. The other part wanted to kick him.

I want to go north, to the Wall. Here, I can pay.“ She gave him the purse. "The Night’s Watch has a castle on the sea. "Eastwatch.” The captain spilled out the silver onto his palm and frowned. “Is this all you have?”

It is not enough, Arya knew without being told. She could see it on his face. “I wouldn’t need a cabin or anything,” she said. “I could sleep down in the hold, or … ”

In almost every chapter we see Arya earnestly trying to go home and her frustration at not being able to reach Winterfell/ her family. So how is Arya returning home and staying with her family not the story that Grrm is writing? What is the point of all these if by the end of it all, Arya just sails away to the West of Westeros? A place that is not even mentioned by her once in the books? A place that would be the death of her. If this is really going to be the conclusion to her storyline then I would say that it’s very disturbing and sadistic.

Nonnie, please don’t misunderstand me. I am not saying that I am right and you are wrong. To be completely honest I am just speculating. I really feel that the way the story is going, Arya will only agree to leave the North (again!) if it means that she can be with a loved one or with someone who feels like home to her.

Also I think I made a mistake by saying that the story was moving on the “right track”. D&d’s was always a fanfiction (with some sprinkles of truth). It had diverged too much to not to be. What I was trying to point out is the inconsistency of it all. If the story is really going to end like this in the books, then whose expectation did D&d subvert? I once read a very articulate post here about how D&d’s ending was a cheap, basterised version of Grrm’s ending. And I agree. Maybe it won’t end the way we want it to, but it sure as hell is not going to be the lazy and tacky ending that D&d gave us.

Gendry will die and some drama will occur between those 3 that leaves Arya and Jon’s relationship strained by the end). I don’t want her to leave but her staying doesn’t seem to be what GRRM is writing.

blog.name: gisellesaintclaire
blog.title: Friend, hero, connoisseur of snacks
blog.description: I will defend Skyler White and Sansa Stark until my dying breath

summary: It would never be the way it had been, he knew. The crow had tricked him into flying, but when he woke up he was broken and the...
body:
It would never be the way it had been, he knew. The crow had tricked him into flying, but when he woke up he was broken and the world was changed.

Bran IV, A Game of Thrones

tags: shows that end better than game of thrones
summary: A Kick-Ass Blog Followed By A List Of Shows That Ended Better Than Game Of Thrones...
title: A Kick-Ass Blog Followed By A List Of Shows That Ended Better Than Game Of Thrones...
body:
A Kick-Ass Blog Followed By A List Of Shows That Ended Better Than Game Of Thrones…

During its last two seasons I felt like I was being held hostage by what was supposed to be the greatest show that has ever graced our screens. Did you feel like that too? If the answer is yes then I am sad for you but also happy that I am not alone.
But there were lessons to learn from the shambolic shambolicy that was the GoT “finale” and season 8 in general. I don’t mean the “beauty in the…

View On WordPress
